qas.question: On which side is a cirque opened?

answers.text: the side that descends into the valley

qas.question: Where does ice start accululating in a glacier?
What is a narrow ridge formed by two cirques eroding back to back called?
What are extremely steep cirques called?
How many sides are closed in a typical cirque?
What is on the side that ascends out of a valley?
What do cirques gorm in mountains?

context: At the start of a classic valley glacier is a bowl-shaped cirque, which has escarped walls on <a4_0>three sides<a4_0/> but is open on <a0_0>the side that descends into the valley<a0_0/>. <a1_0><b5_0>Cirques<b5_0/><a1_0/> are where ice begins to accumulate in a glacier. Two glacial cirques may form back to back and erode their backwalls until only a narrow ridge, called an <a2_0>arête<a2_0/> is left. This structure may result in a <b6_0>mountain pass<b6_0/>. If multiple cirques encircle a single mountain, they create pointed pyramidal peaks; particularly steep examples are called <a3_0><b7_0>horns<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
